Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 46063  
Project Preparatory Technical Assistance (PPTA) 
May 2013 
 
 
 
People’s Republic of China: Xinjiang Tacheng Border 
Cities and Counties Development Project 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
1.  The  Xinjiang  Uygur  Autonomous  Region  (XUAR)  Government  and  Tacheng  Municipal 
Government (TMG), in consultation with the Asian Development Bank (ADB), have identified the 
project components under the proposed ensuing loan. It is a multisector and technically complex 
project, requiring full-scale due diligence in technical, economic, financial, social, resettlement, 
environmental, and institutional aspects through a project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA). 
The  PPTA  will  develop  the  project  suitable for  ADB funding,  in  conjunction  with  the  country 
partnership strategy, sector and operational experience, international best practices, and lessons 
learned from previous projects. 
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
2.  The PPTA will take a two phase approach of consulting services to efficiently use the 
limited  loan  processing  time.  Phase  1  will  be  implemented  while  the  selection  of  consulting 
services of Phase 2 is underway. 
 
3.  Phase  1.  A  team  of  individually  recruited  consultants  will  conduct  the  following  data 
gathering and preliminary assessment: (i) review project components feasibility study report (FSR) 
for consistency with the development program; (ii) check the design criteria for each component 
accords with national standards; (iii) review background and justification for technical proposals 
(namely:  flood  risk  standard,  road  standard  category  per  location,  capacity  and  treatment 
requirements of wastewater treatment plant, water availability assessment for  Baktu Liaota New 
Area and E’min county); (iv) collate data for digital modeling of water supply and sewerage at 
Baktu  Liaota  New  Area;  and  (v)  conduct  training  (namely  on  ADB’s  project  processing  and 
implementation requirements) and stakeholder workshops in each component city/county. These 
consultants will be engaged for about 3.5 person-months (1.5 person-months international and 2 
person-months national) on an intermittent basis.  
 
4.  The Phase 1 consultants will prepare a draft final report and a final report to include (i) 
overview of consistency of proposals with respect to national and regional standards, Twelfth Five-
Year Plan, regional and local master plans and other adopted development plans; (ii) detailed 
technical  assessment  of  FSR  proposals  and  identification  of  technical  options  with 
recommendations for change as necessary; and (iii) specification and supporting input data for 
digital modeling. 
 
5.  Phase 2. Building on the work from the Phase 1, a PPTA consulting firm will prepare a 
comprehensive project feasibility study for an investment project for ADB loan financing. The 
consulting firm will submit the following reports: (i) an inception report within 4 weeks from the start 
of Phase 2, which will finalize the approach, present a detailed work plan and implementation 
schedule for the TA, and identify any needed improvements to the project components for which 
an FSR has been prepared; (ii) an interim report that presents a preliminary description of the 
investment project as a whole—including costing, assessment findings and recommendations, and 
a draft best practice strategy for effective flood protection, water resource management, tree 
screen plantations, development of urban roads and utility services, initial draft of the PAM Section 
V (Financial Management)—to be submitted 12 weeks from the start of Phase 2, together with the 
interim draft IEE, the poverty, social, and gender analyses (including indigenous peoples issues), 
and draft summary resettlement plans; (iii) a revised IEE report within 18 weeks from the start of 
Phase 2; (iv) a social and poverty impact report and draft resettlement plans, ethnic minority

2   
development plans (EMDP), gender action plan (GAP), and social action plan (SAP) within 18 
weeks from the start of Phase 2; (v) a draft final report covering detailed design and cost estimates, 
and economic and financial analyses, which will be submitted 20 weeks from the start of Phase 2, 
together with an FSR for the project; and (vi) a final report, 2 weeks after receiving comments on 
the draft final report from TMG and ADB, which will be issued no later than 6 weeks after issuance 
of the draft final report. 
 
6.  Specific outputs and activities of the PPTA will be as follows: 
 
(i)  Design  and  monitoring  framework.  The  consultants,  in  consultation  with  all 
stakeholders, will develop a design and monitoring framework (DMF) in accordance 
with the Guidelines for Preparing a DMF.1 The consultants will collect and confirm 
baseline indicators, and develop performance indicators for impact, outcome, and 
outputs of the project, including income, poverty, employment, health, gender, and 
other technical, social, and environmental data. The DMF will be developed through 
problem-tree  and  objective-tree  analyses,  risk  and  sensitivity  analyses,  and  a 
participatory approach involving beneficiaries and stakeholders, which will form the 
basis for the project performance management system.   
(ii)  Sector and subsector analysis. The consultants will review the national, provincial, 
and municipal Twelfth Five-Year Plan, the City Master Plans of Tacheng, E’min, 
Yumin, and Tuoli, the development control plan for the Baktu Liaota New Area, and 
other relevant plans. Based on this review, lessons learned from previous ADB-
funded urban projects in the People’s Republic of China and international best 
practices, the consultants will assess the project rationale and justification and give 
recommendations for further strengthening the project design and implementation 
arrangements.  Reflecting  the  sector  review  and  analysis,  the  consultants  will 
prepare  the  necessary  appendixes  for  the  report  and  recommendation  of  the 
President (RRP) of the project, including (a) sector analysis covering the sector 
roadmap, problem tree, and sector results framework; (b) the project’s contribution 
to the ADB results framework; and (c) coordination with development partners for 
the  sector,  all  of  which  in  accordance  with  ADB  guidelines  and  templates.  A 
separate  problem  analysis  table  will  be  prepared  presenting  issues,  causes, 
ongoing interventions, and resultant proposed project inputs, from the technical, 
managerial, institutional, operation and maintenance, social, and financial points of 
view. The consultants, reflecting the sector review and analysis, will also identify 
legal, legislative, regulatory, and institutional reform requirements in view of effective 
management and implementation of urban environment management system and 
services.  
(iii)  Technical design. The consultants will review and improve the technical design of 
all project components to make sure they are technically sound, meet all relevant 
technical  standards,  accord  with  international  good  practice  and  safeguard 
requirements,  and  are  suitable  for  ADB  financing  support.  The  consultants  will 
assess (a) methodology for river training works and flood protection works; (b) likely 
effectiveness of tree screen windbreaks and the best approach to creating urban 
green  areas;  (c)  geotechnical  implications  of  river  bed  dredging,  embankment 
stability, bridge foundations, pipe trenching, and other related facilities; (d) demand 
capacities  and  design  standards  for  utility  service  systems,  and  capacities  of 
supply/treatment facilities; (e) options for bridge superstructure design to create 
pleasing aesthetics; (f) planning requirements for new urban roads and associated

engineering  designs,  responding  to  city-wide  urban transport  network modeling, 
non-motorized transport (NMT) and low-carbon urban development; (g) provision of 
equipment for operation and maintenance of facilities constructed under the project; 
and  (h)  nonstructural  measures  to  improve  urban  environment  and  transport 
services. Based on the analyses and best national and international practices, the 
consultants will recommend improvements to refine the scope and the technical 
design of each project component. 
(iv)  Economic analysis. The consultants will conduct economic analyses of the project, 
including  contingent  valuation  survey  and  analysis,  least-cost  analyses,  cost 
effectiveness analyses and affordability analyses, where applicable, to ensure that 
the economic analysis meets ADB requirements. The economic rationale will be 
developed and economic justification will be evaluated for each project component 
and the project as a whole. The consultants will prepare the required RRP appendix. 
(v)  Financial analysis. The consultants will undertake financial review and analysis of 
each project component as well as detailed assessment of financial performance of 
TMG and cost recovery and tariff analysis, in accordance with ADB’s guidelines.2 
The consultants will prepare the required RRP appendix. 
(vi)  Poverty  and  social  analysis  and  summary  poverty  reduction  and  social 
strategy.  The  consultants  will  help  TMG  engage  a qualified  survey  institute  to 
conduct household surveys for poverty and social analysis in accordance with ADB 
requirements.3 The consultants will prepare a consultation and participation plan, 
conduct key informant and focus group discussions, analyze the survey data, and 
prepare a poverty and social analysis which will make recommendations for design, 
implementation,  and  monitoring to  strengthen the  project's  development  impact. 
Based on this analysis, and in consultation with stakeholders and government, and 
in accordance with ADB guidelines and templates, the consultants will prepare the 
GAP, SAP, and summary poverty reduction and social strategy. 
(vii)  Gender  action  plan. The consultants will work with TMG to conduct a gender 
analysis (with sex-disaggregated data) and formulate a GAP with the objective of 
ensuring that the project maximizes benefits for women and meets effective gender 
mainstreaming categorization requirements. Based on this poverty and social and 
gender analysis, and in consultation with stakeholders and government, and in 
accordance with ADB guidelines,4 the consultants will assist TMG to prepare GAP 
and implementation arrangements. 
(viii)  Community participation plan and public awareness campaign program. The 
consultants  will  prepare,  through  a  participatory  approach,  a  comprehensive 
communications strategy and detailed development plan for community involvement 
and public awareness on urban planning, river ecosystem, environmental protection, 
public health, and road safety based on the 2012 guidelines on participation.5 
(ix)  Environmental assessment. The consultants will provide guidance to the domestic 
EIA institutes, review the domestic environment impact statements (EIS) prepared 
for the project components, and ensure that all domestic EISs are approved by

relevant environment protection authorities. Based on the review of the EISs, the 
consultants  will  help  prepare  a  consolidated  project  IEE  report  including 
environment management plan (EMP) in ADB's required format and complying with 
ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). The consultants will assess the capacity 
of the executing agency and implementing agencies for environmental management, 
monitoring  and  supervision,  and  recommend  required  measures  for  capacity 
building and institutional strengthening. The consultants will assist the executing 
agency  with  meaningful  consultation  and  participation  during  IEE,  and  the 
establishment  of  a  grievance  redress  mechanism.  The  consultants  will  prepare 
contractor specifications for environmental management and internal monitoring. 
The  consultants  will  also  establish  environmental  baseline  indicators  and 
performance targets for the DMF, and prepare the required RRP appendixes. 
(x)  Involuntary resettlement assessment. The consultants will assist the executing 
and implementing agencies to prepare resettlement plans in accordance with ADB 
requirements. 6  TMG  will  engage  a  qualified  survey  institute  to  conduct  a 
socioeconomic survey. The consultants will use the survey results to conduct the 
social impact assessment(s), initiate a consultation process and improve and finalize 
the resettlement plans. The consultants will also prepare the required RRP appendix 
and a summary resettlement plan. 
(xi)  Ethnic minority (indigenous peoples) assessment. The consultants will conduct 
a thorough scoping of indigenous peoples issues in the project area and will assist 
the  executing  and  implementing  agencies  to  prepare  an  ethnic  minority 
development plan in accordance with ADB requirements.7 Based on findings from 
the poverty and social analysis, they will conduct an impact assessment, initiate a 
consultative process with ethnic minority communities impacted by the project, and 
formulate appropriate mitigation and enhancement measures. 
(xii)  Risk assessment and management plan. The consultants will assess the financial 
management system, accounting rules and practices, administrative procedures, 
internal control and audit, external audit, and procurement capacity and practices, of 
TMG  and  relevant  municipal  governments.  Based  on  this  assessment,  the 
consultants will work with stakeholders to identify potential project-related risks in 
three  specific  thematic  issues,  namely:  (a)  public  financial  management,  (b) 
procurement; and (c) anticorruption and prepare a draft governance risk assessment 
and management plan. Funds flow and disbursement arrangements will also be 
identified reflecting the governance assessment. The consultants will also prepare 
the required RRP appendix. 
(xiii)  Project  administration  manual.  The  consultants  will  prepare  a  project 
administration manual (PAM), which will (a) include a project implementation plan, 
including  project  readiness  filters;  (b)  specify  project  implementation  roles  and 
responsibilities  of  TMG,  the  implementing  agency,  and  ADB;  (c)  identify 
implementation arrangements, including detailed costs and financing plan, financial 
management,  consulting  services  and  procurement,  safeguards,  performance 
monitoring,  evaluation,  reporting  and  communications,  and  accountability 
mechanism; and (d) include an S-curve quarterly projection of contract awards and 
disbursement for the whole duration of project implementation. The PAM will be 
prepared through a consultative process and will be agreed on initially at loan fact-
finding.  An  initial  draft  of  the  PAM  Section  V  (Financial  Management)  will  be 
included in the interim report.

(xiv)  Procurement plan and procurement documents. The consultants will undertake 
a comprehensive procurement capacity assessment of the executing agency and 
implementing agency in accordance with ADB guidelines and template.8 Based on 
this  assessment  and  technical  requirements  of  each  project  component,  the 
consultants will prepare a procurement plan. The consultants will also prepare bid 
documents for  the  packages  under  different  procurement modes,  and  terms of 
reference for project implementation consultants.   
(xv)  Institutional  strengthening  and  capacity  development  plan.  Based  on 
institutional assessment on financial management, procurement, planning, technical 
engineering, operation and maintenance, and project management capacities of 
TMG and relevant municipal governments, the consultants will prepare a capacity 
development  plan  presenting  specific  actions  for  trainings  and  institutional 
strengthening  measures  to  enhance  the  capacity  of  the  executing  agency, 
implementing agency, and other concerned agencies to meet operational needs of 
project  implementation and  to  ensure future managerial, technical  and financial 
sustainability of operations. The consultants will conduct training workshops based 
on the capacity development plan. 
(xvi)  Knowledge  product.  The  consultants  will  prepare  guidance  notes  for 
environmentally sustainable and socially inclusive urban expansion in small cities 
with a dual urban-rural economy.

C.  Cost Estimates and Proposed Financing Arrangement 
8.  The TA is estimated to cost $970,000 equivalent, of which $750,000 equivalent will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB's technical assistance special fund (TASF-other sources). The 
government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office accommodation, 
office  supplies,  secretarial  assistance,  domestic  transportation,  communication  facilities  for 
consultants, and other in-kind contributions. The government has been informed that approval of 
the  TA  does  not  commit  ADB  to  finance  any  ensuing  project. The  detailed  cost  estimate  is 
presented in Table A4.2.

D.  Consulting Services Composition of the Expert Team 
 
9.  In Phase 1, 3 individual experts with a total of 3.5 person-months (1.5 international and 2.0 
person-months national) will be engaged through the individual consultant selection. In Phase 2 an 
international consulting firm and individual consultants with a total consulting inputs of 47.5 person-
months (15.5 person-months international and 32.0 person-months national) will be engaged on 
the basis of the quality- and cost-based selection method, with a quality-cost ratio of 90:10, using 
simplified  technical  proposal  procedure,  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  The  terms  of  reference  for  the  PPTA 
consultants are described in the attachment. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements

11.  TA reports will be prepared in English and Chinese. Five copies of each report in English 
will be submitted to ADB, and 10 copies of both English and Chinese reports will be submitted to 
the executing agency. The reports should address all aspects of the terms of reference to the level 
of detail appropriate for the given stage of the TA and should include revised project logical 
frameworks. The consultants will present the key findings of each report in tripartite workshops to 
be held after the submission of the inception report, interim report, and draft final report. Members 
of the project leading group, representatives of the development and reform commission, the 
finance bureau, key agencies, local communities, and ADB staff will participate in the workshops 
and the tripartite meetings. The proposed TA processing and implementation schedule is listed in
